Award.AwardTitle: Microwave imaging of dynamic dielectric environments: Application to breast cancer detection

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop and evaluate 3-D quantitative microwave inverse scattering algorithms for dynamic dielectric environments, such as occur with use of a contrast agent in breast cancer screening, hormonal agents in cancer prevention, or various therapies in cancer treatment. The approach is to combine scattered field data from multiple scans over time of a dielectric environment into a single imaging problem through the use of spatial and temporal basis functions. Sparsity-inducing regularizers are applied to the basis coefficients to obtain high-resolution images of the changes in dielectric properties. The algorithms are validated using computational studies with 3-D MRI-derived numerical phantoms having a high level of anatomical realism and experimental studies with heterogeneous anthropomorphic physical phantoms.

Intellectual Merit: Innovative microwave inverse scattering algorithms are developed that exploit prior knowledge of the dynamic dielectric environment to overcome the limitations of the single-scan inverse scattering problem. Demonstration of these novel imaging algorithms using numerical and experimental testbeds provides evidence of their effectiveness.

Broader Impacts: This project has a positive impact on the health of women worldwide through development of improved breast imaging methods. The algorithms are also applicable to nondestructive evaluation. Engineering-grand-challenges case studies on breast cancer detection are developed for middle school and first-year undergraduate students. The project's emphasis on women's health is leveraged to recruit female students. Institutional programs are employed to involve minorities and undergraduates in the project. All students involved in the project receive interdisciplinary training at the interface of signal processing, electromagnetics, and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microwave breast imaging uses non-ionizing signals similar to cell-phone emissions to sense electrical properties of breast tissue. These properties can be modified in the clinic by introducing biocompatible nanoparticles that accumulate only in a tumor. Microwave images from a single scan typically have low resolution. One of the primary outcomes of this project was the development of a three-dimensional microwave breast imaging algorithm that combines data from multiple scans (i.e. before and after the nanoparticle contrast agent alters the tumor properties) and exploits the localized nature of the contrast enhancement to obtain high-resolution images of the change in dielectric properties. The performance of the imaging algorithm for tumor detection was demonstrated using data from computer-simulated scans of "virtual patients", that is, highly realistic numerical breast models, and from experimental scans of physical breast phantoms.

Additional project outcomes include the following innovations related to microwave breast imaging: optimization of the initial guess for microwave imaging algorithms based on iterative microwave inverse scattering techniques, beamforming enhancement of microwave inverse scattering algorithms for mitigating the effects of noise on the imaging accuracy, the development of two additional types of high-resolution microwave breast imaging algorithms (based on a level set method and the use of spatial prior constraints), and the determination that array configurations with greater design flexibilities – specifically arrays with non-uniformly-oriented antennas – do not degrade and in fact may enhance the quality of information in the scattering data measured by the antenna array surrounding the breast.

Project outcomes were disseminated in 12 conference presentations and the following five journal papers:

1)      S. M. Aguilar, M. A. Al-Joumayly, M. J. Burfeindt, N. Behdad, and S. C. Hagness, "Multi-band miniaturized patch antennas for a compact, shielded microwave breast imaging array," IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation, vol. 62, no. 3, pp. 1221-1231, March 2014.

2)      M J. Burfeindt, J. D. Shea, B. D. Van Veen, and S. C. Hagness, "Beamforming-enhanced inverse scattering for microwave breast imaging," IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation, vol. 62, no. 10, pp. 5126-5132, Oct. 2014.

3)      R. O. Mays, N. Behdad, and S. C. Hagness, "A TSVD analysis of the impact of polarization on microwave breast imaging using an enclosed array of miniaturized patch antennas," IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters, vol. 14, pp. 418-421, Feb. 2015. 

4)      F. Gao, B. D. Van Veen, and S. C. Hagness, "Sensitivity of the distorted Born iterative method to the initial guess in microwave breast imaging," IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation, vol. 63, no. 8, pp. 3540-3547, Aug. 2015.

5)      T. J. Colgan, S. C. Hagness, and B. D. Van Veen, "A 3D level set method for microwave breast imaging," IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering, vol. 62, no. 10, pp. 2526-2534, Oct. 2015.

This project provided six Ph.D. students, including two women, with broad interdisciplinary training at the interface of signal processing, electromagnetics, and medical imaging. Four of the students completed Ph.D. dissertations during the project period. One of the female Ph.D. students received the first place award in the student paper competition at the 2015 North American Radio Science Meeting in Vancouver, BC Canada.

The general approach for imaging dynamic dielectric environments is also broadly applicable to any inverse problem involving a contrast condition in which the contrast is expected to modify a small number of unknowns.
